requirements: Color must not be the only means of conveying message type
Appropriate ARIA roles must be used (alert for errors, contentinfo for others)
ARIA live regions must be properly implemented
Text contrast must meet WCAG AA standards
Icons must have appropriate semantic meaning
Screen reader support must be comprehensive

bestPractices: Keep message content brief and to the point using plain language
Apply the correct message type based on context and urgency
Ensure each message type is visually distinct through consistent styling
Include clear instructions on what the user should do next when relevant
Place messages where they are contextually relevant
Ensure sufficient color contrast for all message types
Design messages to be fully responsive across all device sizes
Use appropriate ARIA attributes for screen reader accessibility

when_to_use: Communicate important status information (errors, warnings, success, information)
Alert users to critical information requiring attention
Provide contextual notifications within a page
Inform users about system status changes
when_not_to_use: Information is not time-sensitive or doesn't require immediate attention
Multiple notifications that could overwhelm the user
Information better presented as inline form validation
Complex information requiring user interaction beyond acknowledgment
Collecting user input (use form components instead)
Messages that would interrupt user workflow unnecessarily

variations.name: Error Messages
variations.description: Critical problems that prevent action completion

variations.name: Warning Messages
variations.description: Potential issues requiring attention but not preventing actions

knownIssues: Mobile responsiveness: Longer message text may create readability challenges on very small screens
Colour reliance: Strong colour association may create barriers for users with colour vision deficiencies
Dismissible functionality: Current implementation doesn't include dismissible functionality
